text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

One in four women experience
rape or attempted rape
while they're in college.
Think about that.

When we think about
sexual assault,

we think about someone sneaking
up behind you in a dark alley

and grabbing you, but
that's not how it happens.

70% of sexual
assault takes place

between friends and
classmates, in places
where you feel comfortable.

So you're not going to have a
can of pepper spray with you,

and even if you did,
you're not going

to feel comfortable using
that against someone you know.

We're a team of entrepreneurs,
engineers, and designers

who came together
because of our shared

experiences with
sexual assault. And we

spent the whole last year
talking to over 1,600 people

and working with sexual
assault survivors, advocacy
organizations, and universities.

We have developed a super
discreet personal safety

device that's designed
for real life situations,

whether you're just
feeling uncomfortable,
or it's an emergency.

It's hidden inside things
that you already use,
starting with jewelry.

Say you're on a bad date
or in a terrible happy hour
conversation.
We've all been there.

Press the device once and
receive a fake phone call
to get out of any situation.

Or if it escalates,
press and hold

to send an emergency message
to your designated contacts,

telling them exactly where you
are and that you need help.

We have partnerships with
nine jewelry designers,

and manufacturers are
launching a pilot.

And with your help, we're going
to reinvent personal security
and protect millions of women.
Thank you.
[CHEERING]
